name: Petra's Stone and Mineral Collection (Steinasafn Petru)
description: Petra's Stone and Mineral Collection in the tiny East Iceland village of Stöðvarfjörður represents one of Iceland's most remarkable and touching museums—a lifetime's passionate accumulation of stones, minerals, and geological specimens assembled over decades by Petra María Sveinsdóttir (1922-2012), a local woman with no formal geological training but an extraordinary eye for beauty and an obsessive dedication to gathering Iceland's mineral wealth. What began as childhood fascination with colorful pebbles grew into a consuming passion that led Petra to roam the mountains, beaches, and volcanic landscapes of East Iceland for over 70 years, collecting specimens that caught her eye for their colors, shapes, crystal formations, or geological interest. By her death at age 89, Petra had amassed a staggering collection of tens of thousands of specimens—some sources estimate 70,000-100,000 pieces—that fill every available surface, shelf, table, and display case in her former home and adjacent buildings, creating an almost overwhelming visual experience of color, texture, and geological diversity. The collection includes spectacular examples of Iceland's volcanic minerals: zeolites in every color from white through yellow, pink, and blue-green; calcite crystals ranging from transparent Iceland spar to colored varieties; jasper and chalcedony nodules displaying intricate banding and patterns; volcanic glass (obsidian) in blacks and browns; agates with concentric ring patterns; and countless specimens that defy easy identification, representing the incredible mineralogical diversity produced by Iceland's ongoing volcanic activity and hydrothermal systems. Petra arranged her collection not by scientific taxonomy but by aesthetic appeal—groupings by color, size, or visual harmony that create an artistic rather than academic presentation. The domestic setting preserves Petra's personal environment: her home remains much as she left it, with stones covering tables, filling shelves, arranged in gardens, and displayed in cases built by her husband to accommodate the ever-growing collection. The effect is magical—walking through rooms where every surface showcases natural beauty creates an almost museum-fatigue inducing experience, yet the sheer volume and variety keep visitors discovering new specimens and marveling at nature's capacity for creating beauty from rock and mineral. Beyond the minerals themselves, Petra's collection tells a human story of passion, dedication, and the transformative power of obsession channeled into constructive pursuit. Petra became a beloved local character, known throughout East Iceland for her solitary mountain wanderings in search of new specimens, and her collection brought visitors to Stöðvarfjörður—a village that might otherwise see little tourism—helping support the local economy while sharing her love of stones. The museum continues to operate thanks to family members and supporters who maintain Petra's legacy, keeping her home and collection accessible to visitors who want to experience this unique testament to one person's lifelong passion.
